title: Do Boston city councilors deserve a pay raise? - Local news
text:
An analysis of Boston city councilors’ work habits by The Boston Globe revealed weeks-long absenses from City Hall, as well as late arrivals and early departures.
The Globe reviewed attendance records, private calendars, and data from City Hall’s executive parking garage, as the councilors push to give themselves a considerable pay raise.
Related Link Get today’s headlines right in your inbox Councilors disputed the validity of the findings.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below “I’m on the phone 24 hours [a day],” Councilor Timothy McCarthy told the Globe . “This is unfair. I work very hard, and I don’t take a lot of days off.”
According to the Globe , McCarthy’s schedule during his first year in office showed golf penciled in on 14 workdays.
“Trying to use the entering of an access code to a garage as a gauge of the amount of time councilors work is not valid,” Council President Bill Linehan told the Globe in an email. “Schedules only represent a portion of the work.”
Read the full Globe story.
Boston City Hall throughout the years :
 The Old City Hall was built on the same location as America’s first public school, the Boston Latin School. Old City Hall took three years to build, and after completion in 1865, 38 Boston mayors served from the building. It was used until a new City Hall was completed in 1968. Boston Globe Archives When this photo was taken in 1906, what we now know as Government Center was Scollay Square. That neighborhood was bulldozed in 1962 to make room for the new City Hall and plaza. Officials saw the project as a way to bring Boston out of economic stagnation. Boston Globe Archives The winning design for a new City Hall (pictured above) was chosen by a seven-member jury and designed by three men who taught at Columbia University in New York. The winners, Gerhard Kallmann, Michael McKinnell, and Edward Knowles, later began their own architecture firm. Boston Globe Archives On September 18, 1963, ground was broken for the new City Hall building. Walter Pages of Boston wielded a shovel dressed in Colonial clothes, Boston Mayor John F. Collins was joined by Gov. Endicott Peabody and John B. Hynes, the former mayor of Boston (men pictured left to right). UPI Photo The design for the new City Hall was met with mixed feelings from the public. Many opposed the design due to its lack of congruence with the rest of the city’s buildings. Joe Dennehy / The Boston Globe Boston Globe reporter Bud Collins sat in the mayor’s office on the fifth floor of the new City Hall building when this picture was snapped. Faneuil Hall and the steeple of the Old North Church could be seen out the large windows. Boston Globe Archives In January 1969, the Boston City Coucil met in their new chambers for the first time. They weren’t happy about exposed wires and outdated desks, and voiced those concerns to the Government Center Comission. Philip N. Preston / The Boston Globe In May 1969, the new City Hall had a very modern feel. Edison Farrand / The Boston Globe This photo taken from the 13th floor of the New England Merchants National Bank tower showed just how large City Hall Plaza would be. Jack Sheahan / The Boston Globe City Hall reflected in a puddle in the plaza in 1991. Yunghi Kim / The Boston Globe An overhead view of City Hall Plaza from 1998 shows how vast the space really is. The 8-acre plaza is frequently used for Boston events like concerts, markets, and festivals. The two-stage Boston Calling music festival fills the plaza each year for two weekends of music. Boston Globe Archives Last year, in an attempt to spruse up City Hall, tape was added to the main staircase in the building’s atrium. Headless mannequins were also added to display work students at the School of Fashion Design had produced. Suzanne Kreiter / The Boston Globe Chairs for lounging were added outside of City Hall in the plaza for visitors to enjoy on nice summer days. Jonathan Wiggs / The Boston Globe Astroturf was also added outside of City Hall Plaza for visitors to hang out on. The makeshift “Front Lawn” was put in place to make City Hall more of an attraction for Boston visitors and residents. Keith Bedford / The Boston Globe
